title: The point of the game is fun
body:
Current punishment system forces you to be constantly focused on filtering what you say. You must overcome your automatic response to being bullied or being accused of something you didn't do. Current punishment system forces you to put active though into something that is supposed to be automated.

It is actively unfun to stay fully aware and conscious instead of blissfully grinding games, venting and sharing any negativity, as humans do when they get stressed. 

As someone not threatened by current punishment system, I _suggest_ scrapping it completely with no replacement.

No, you can actually get banned for passive-aggressive stuff, sarcasm, whining and even typing too much - anything that can be interpreted in a negative manner. You can also get banned for saying some of peculiar words that Riot does not disclose, regardless of context.

I would say that shit got as oppressive as it gets and it came to the point where it impairs social interaction. If you like something, you can say it. If you don't like something - you shut up.

> Current punishment system forces you to be constantly focused on filtering what you say.

If what you say is normally spiteful, vitriolic, inflammatory, offensive, and generally detrimental, then, yeah, it's gonna force you to either filter yourself or hit the road.

You act like there's absolutely no repercussions whatsoever for saying literally anything off the top of your head in common society. If you went out and started yelling, insulting, and harassing someone just because you didn't like their gait, you're going to be seen as an asshole, and people aren't gonna wanna deal with you.

And when it comes to establishments (grocery/convenience stores, restaurants, etc.), even those places have standards for acceptable conduct, much like League does. If you start yelling and wailing at the top of your lungs, having a category 5 manchild meltdown, or start bickering at other people because you don't like the food that they like, etc. - you're going to be asked to stop, and if you keep it up, you'll be made to leave.

> You must overcome your automatic response to being bullied or being accused of something you didn't do.

Again; if the automatic response is inflammatory, yes, you're going to have to overcome that. It doesn't take much effort to put second thought to deciding whether or not to tell this guy to "fuck off" - you can mute them and report them post-game, and suffer no consequences yourself.

Flaming someone who accuses you of doing something you didn't only validates their claims, and makes you liable to be punished.

To repeat what _should_ be common internet wisdom by now: _Don't feed the troll._

> Current punishment system forces you to put active though into something that is supposed to be automated.

What, responding to people, or reporting people? Either way, it's not supposed to be automated. In the former case, you're dealing with other people, and having a modicum of tact is pretty much necessary - and showing a modicum of respect is _expected_ of you.

And in the latter case - you're reporting someone. You're making a claim that "this" person broke the rules. If there's no basis to your claim, and no effort on your part to prove that they broke them, then guess what? Your report was wasted.

> It is actively unfun to stay fully aware and conscious instead of blissfully grinding games, venting and sharing any negativity, as humans do when they get stressed.

It is actively unfun to deal with people whose bullshit we don't want to hear when we're trying to play a game. If you need to vent to someone, find someone who's willing to listen. A sibling, a parent, a friend, etc. - but don't dump your vitriol on your teammates.

> As someone not threatened by current punishment system, I _suggest_ scrapping it completely with no replacement.

And with that suggestion, flaming, trolling, etc. would become rampant, and the game would be 100x _**less**_ fun.

I would say it's a suggestion that would be taken under advisement, but frankly, it's not a suggestion worth taking at all.
